replyContent: The app uses an algorithm based on Bluetooth signal strength to make calculations about risk. It is based on distance between app users and how much time they have spent near each other. Bluetooth signal strength is reduced through walls, therefore less likely to satisfy the criteria. Find out more: https://faq.covid19.nhs.uk/article/KA-01165/en-us

content: عععح

The app needs a lot of improvement Not convinced the app can judge distance correctly it relies on signal strength of Bluetooth signal but as far as i can see this could vary significantly depending upon the environment the phone is in and other factors . For example the signal strength would be affected by whether you have the phone in your hand or in a pocket, if you are outdoors or indoors, if you are in a environment with metal that will cause reflected signals (e.g. public transport). Also signal strengths may be affected depending upon the model of phone you and the close contact has. The initial notifications do not include the exposure date (the exposure date is hidden away in the menu "settings/other data menu". The app also does not take into account vaccination status, whether the people were wearing masks at time of exposure, whether you were facing towards or away from a person at time of exposure, had protective screens around them and when you check into a venue you cant check out (so if you went for breakfast at a venue it would show you at that venue until it closes (so if its a pub that could perhaps be 14 hours later). so to improve the app I think the following should be considered Your vaccination status should be considered when calculating the risk All close contact & venue notifications should include the exposure date exposure date (and some kind of approximate time if possible) Exposure information should be clearly visible in menus not hidden away You should be able to check out of a venue Perhaps you can enter what setting you are in if you want to or the app takes into account the precautions in a venue after you check into a venue Vaccination status should be included in app and the app should take this into account when you have a close contact notification

content: For whatever reason this app decided to trip out on me and I ended up receiving a notification to self-Isolate for 11 days. Long story short my employer informed me that my notification appears to have been triggered as though someone had inputted symptoms, asked me to prove I hadn't (Obviously how can one prove something that never happened at all), 119 were zero help just palmed me off to ACAS... so with all that being said my employer took action to dismiss me for Gross misconduct. So thanks.

Most of the app is user friendly but using Bluetooth only is a bad design. What happens with those who live in remote/rural areas; how will their Bluetooth connect? Why not wireless or even 3G, or would that cost another several billion pounds to implement...

There seems to be a fundamental problem with the messaging for the use of this app, and that is that it's just as important to check out as check in. If you don't check out, then it marks that you've been there until 23.59 that day, even if you were in at 08.00 for 10mins. So if someone reports testing positive and visited the same place as you on the same day, you both may be recorded as having visited at the same time and be contacted, even if that wasn't the case! BAM. Self-Isolation.

replyContent: Hello Matt, the app can only accept test result codes which specifically state they are for use with the app. If your Lateral Flow Test is positive and you register this online, then you will be provided with a test result code for use with the app. Find out more: https://faq.covid19.nhs.uk/article/KA-01394/en-us.

content: Kinda dumb. It assumes you're at a venue from check-in to midnight, which is unlikely given the restrictive COVID-19 laws. A check-out feature is necessary. The fact it needs Bluetooth means that your battery life will be affected instead of connecting to mobile data and using a service either similar to or connected to the native map apps (Google Maps for Android). In theory, it's a good idea, but it's horrifically unoptimised and is only useful because you need it to go into places.
replyContent: If you don't visit another venue then the app will check you out at midnight. If it’s identified that people that later tested positive for COVID-19 have been to a venue, anyone who was at that venue on that day may get an alert. This alert will usually tell you to be aware and to get a test if you develop symptoms. https://covid19.nhs.uk/
